description.narrative: Conservation-oriented management of forests and wetlands to achieve multiple benefits

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative:
Outcome I: 1.1. Number of business organizations involved in sustainable habitat management at target PAs that is profitable for them 1.2. Representation of women in sustainable use activities associated with business plans developed under Outcome 1 1.3. Area of natural, highly productive foraging grounds within the living territory of the European bison's micro population in the Nalibokski Reserve (50,000 ha) 1.4. Spatial distribution of bison throughout the micro population's living area 1.5. Area of open sedge mires where sustainable resource use and vegetation management is practiced 1.6. Dynamics of water level throughout the year 1.7. Population size of indicator species in Zvanets and Sporovsky Reserves 1.8. Area of open, sustainably used meadows at Turov and Pogost Meadows 1.9. Population size of species during spring migration (Widgeon, Ruff, Black-tailed godwit) 1.10. Population size of nesting indicator bird species (Great snipe, Black-tailed godwit, Terek sandpiper, Redshank) 1.11. Numbers of organized tourists in the PAs
Outcome 2: 2.1. Area of forest biotopes transferred to the protection category 2.2. Number of Forestries that envisage forestry management plans in line with sustainable use of protected biotopes 2..3 Number of employees of the Ministry of Forestry trained in the sustainable use of protected biotopes 2.4. Official policy and document on future use of forest hydro amelioration systems
Outcome 3: 3.1. Area of territory with associations of sedge mires 3.2.Population size of globally threatened species: Aquatic warbler, Greater spotted eagle, Curlew, Great snipe. 3.3. Area of restored sedge fen mires 3.4. Area of vegetation associations on restored mire 3.5. Greenhouse gas emissions at following pilot sites: 12,456 ha of forest peatland; 1,025 ha of open peatlands 3.6. Number of genetically valuable bison transferred from different micro populations in Belarus and Poland to Nalibokski to increase diversity 3.7. Number of genetic pass

comment.narrative:
Outcome I: 1.1. No business organizations involved in management of target PAs 1.2. 0% 1.3. Not more than 100 ha 1.4. During late autumn and early spring bison feed mainly on adjacent agricultural lands 1.5. Sporovsky 500 ha; Zvanets 100 ha 1.6. Unstable water level (30-50 cm above or 30 cm below ground level) during May-July; Water mineralization is from 300 to 450 mg/l 1.7. Species B/L pop. size: (i) Sporovsky Reserve (Aquatic warbler -500-700 males; Greater spotted eagle - 1-2 pairs); (ii) Zvanets Reserve (AW -2,100-4,400 males; Greater spotted eagle - 0-2 pairs; Curlew - 0-4 pairs) 1.8. Turov Meadow 100 ha; Pogost 0 ha 1.9. Species B/L pop. size: (i) Turov Meadow (Widgeon-10,000-20,000); Ruff - 10,000-30,000; Black-tailed godwit - 3,000); (ii) Pogost Meadow (W-100; Ruff - 0; Black-tailed godwit - 0) 1.10. Species B/L pop. size: (i) Turov Meadow (Great snipe-100 males); Black-tailed godwit- 30 pairs; Terek sandpiper - 5 pairs; Redshank- 120 pairs; (ii) Pogost Meadow (GS-0 males); BTG- 0 pairs; TS- 0 pairs; R- 0 pairs 1.11. Nalibokski -250; Sporovsky - 4,500; Turov Meadow - 340
Outcome 2: 2.1. 3,000 ha of forest lands with rare biotopes are transferred into protection 2.2. 3 forestry enterprises 2.3. Employees of the Ministry of Forestry do not have experience in sustainable use of rare biotopes needing special protection 2.4. Due to the lack of data for evaluation of the current state of forest hydro amelioration systems, there is no coordinated policy on their further use
Outcome 3: 3.1. Dikoe 250 ha; Servech 200 ha 3.2. Species B/L pop. size: (i) Dikoe- Aquatic warbler (150-200 males); Greater spotted eagle (4-5 pairs); (ii) Servech - AW- 31-38 males; Curlew - (0-2 pairs); Great snipe- (21-30 males) 3.3.There is only one sedge fen mire in the Grodno Region - the "Svisloch" mire – with an area of 200 ha 3.4. Sedge communities on the peatland Dokudovskoe (1,200 ha) occupy no more than 20 ha 3.5. Carbon dioxide emissions are about 10-20 tons per ha per year 3

1.1 Improvement of nature conservation legislation aimed at conservation of globally threatened species and their habitats, as well as of the system of registration of nature protection areas. 1.2 Improved habitat conditions for the European bison micro population in the Naliboksky Reserve through creation of mosaic meadow grounds among dense forests. 1.3 Profitable use of cranberry reserves as an effective way of mire ecosystem conservation. 1.4 Financially self-sustaining wetland biomass harvesting and processing program launched at two PAs (Sporovsky and Zvanets) in partnership with local businesses. 1.5 Improved financial sustainability of measures for conservation of floodplain meadows (key habitats of globally threatened species) through introduction of technology of sustainable use of meadows for mowing and grazing and through development of ecological tourism . 1.6 Ecological tourism developed at key protected areas, resulting in improved financial sustainability of protected areas and raised awareness about importance of globally biodiversity conservation. 2.1 Forest biotopes, subject to special protection, are identified, approved and sustainably managed at an area of 150,000 ha 2.2 Avoided degradation of inefficiently drained forest peatlands (260,000 ha) as a result of development and implementation of the Scheme of Sustainable Use of Drained Forest Peatlands, defining ways of use of each peatland. Demonstration of approaches for the ecological rehabilitation of inefficiently drained peatlands at an area of about 12,456 ha. 3.1 Restored habitats (about 1,820 ha) of globally threatened species (Aquatic warbler, Greater spotted eagle, Great snipe, Black-tailed godwit) within the most important protected areas (Servech, Dikoe) through control of vegetation succession (control of the spread of shrubs and reeds) and optimization of hydrological regime. 3.3 Targeted measures to stabilize populations of insufficiently studied globally threatened species.

1.1 The proposals submitted by wetland science and biodiversity experts have been consolidated and adapted. Proposals for the chapters General Provisions, Government Control of Mires (Peatlands) Protection and Management, Involvement of Individuals and Legal Entities in Addressing Conservation and Management of Mires (Peatlands), Supervision (Compliance Monitoring) and Dispute Settlement, Responsibility for the Conservation and Management of Mires (Peatlands), Concluding Clause have been prepared. Draft Law of the Republic of Belarus On the Conservation and Management of Mires (Peatlands), a rationale for the adoption of the law, and a financial feasibility study have been prepared. The prepared draft law and respective rationales have been submitted to the MNREP. 1.2 6 monitoring visits to the territory of Naliboksky National Landscape Reserve have been organized to assess the progress and effectiveness of project activities. The assessment of the financial and organizational capacity of the partner (Naliboksky Reserve) has been conducted to conclude an agreement on the joint implementation of project activities. Based on the list of equipment approved by the MNREP, part of the equipment has been purchased to maintain food plots for bison in the best possible state and to monitor the effectiveness of activities. 1.3 In accordance with the provisions of the approved project document, a marketing strategy has been prepared for the distribution of ODO PKF "Arzhanitsa" products, produced as a result of cranberry processing, to the entire territory of Belarus and beyond, in terms of implementing a responsible attitude to the use of resources in bog ecosystems and promoting the principle of non-depleting economically justified use of bogs. 1.4 The purchased equipment for shrubs and reeds has been transferred to the Sporovsky and Zvanets Reserves according to the Project Document. 1.5 The assessment of the financial and organizational capacity of the partners (Scientific and Practical Centre of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus on Animal Husbandry) has been conducted to conclude an agreement on the joint implementation of project activities. 1.6 Activities to organize sustainable ecotourism focused on the demonstration of European bison and other wild animals of the Nalibokskaya Puscha have been elaborated and coordinated with the Ministry of Forestry. The strategy and plan for the development of ecotourism at project's target PAs (Olmany Mires, Turov Meadow, Servech, Zvanets, Sporovsky) have been developed. 2.1 The forest and nature conservation legislation has been analyzed, and proposals on its harmonization with respect to designation of protection status for biodiversity-valuable forest plots by ensuring that such plots can be transferred to protected biotopes under the legislation have been prepared. Development of proposals to amend regulations TKP 17.12-06-2014 (02120) "Rules of Designating and Protecting Typical and Rare Biotopes, Typical and Rare Natural Landscapes" with due regard for the established practice. The inventory of rare and typical biotopes in the territory of Dyatlovo, Ivye, and Beshenkovichi Forestries has been conducted, proposals on integrating the system of their sustainable management into the projects on the organization of forest management have been developed. Respective report prepared.6 pilot sites of rare and typical biotopes have been created at the project territory of Dyatlovo Forestry. Representatives of 35forestries and other organizations involved in the development and implementation of forest management projects were trained at a seminar on the identification and sustainable use of rare and typical biotopes. Two monitoring visits have been made to Dyatlovo Forestry where project activities are implemented to coordinate activities and participate in the training workshop. 2.2 The methodology and criteria for the assessment of the cost efficiency and environmental efficiency of forest hydro ameliorative systems and their influence on forest and mire ecosystems (biodiversity, productivity, state) have been developed and tested based on the inventory of forest hydro ameliorative systems of four forestries. Ways of the further use of the forest hydro ameliorative systems at pilot forestries have been determined. Scientific substantiation of ecological rehabilitation of inefficiently drained forest peatlands (hydro-forest reclamation systems), acts of site selection and design specifications for four territories: Berezovik in the Vileika District of the Minsk Region, Zhada in the Miory and Sharkovshchinsky Districts of the Vitebsk Region; "Ostrovo" in the Smorgon district of the Grodno region, Verech in the Gorodoksky district, Vitebsk region; (project areas can be changed while retaining the total area as agreed with local land users) are developed. Water level sensors (8 sensors) were purchased and installed in the pilot areas. 3.1 Cycle of preparatory works for the environmental rehabilitation of the disturbed Dokudovskoye peatland organized, coordinated, scientifically substantiated and supported. 3.3 The inventory of key habitats of the globally threatened species in Brest and Gomel Oblasts and the assessment of the state of their populations have been completed. 40 passports and conservation obligations for land plots and/or water bodies for transfer to land users for protection and sustainable use and organization of the sustainable management of the identified key habitats of globally threatened species have been prepared and transferred according to the established procedure. Species and territories have been identified where the implementation of pilot activities is planned, the cost of activities has been calculated, necessary approvals and permits have been acquired. Vegetation maps, correlation of areas of plant associations were prepared and their condition was investigated in the project areas (Zvanets, Sporovsky, Servech, Dikoe, Turovsky meadow, Pogost) prior to the implementation of the project activities. The assessment of the spatial distribution of European bison in the Naliboksky Reserve, the frequency of visiting food plots and agricultural lands prior to the beginning of the project.

1.1 Improvement of nature conservation legislation aimed at conservation of globally threatened species and their habitats, as well as of the system of registration of nature protection areas. 1.2 Improved habitat conditions for the European bison micro population in the Naliboksky Reserve through creation of mosaic meadow grounds among dense forests. 1.3 Profitable use of cranberry reserves as an effective way of mire ecosystem conservation. 1.4 Financially self-sustaining wetland biomass harvesting and processing program launched at two PAs (Sporovsky and Zvanets) in partnership with local businesses. 1.5 Improved financial sustainability of measures for conservation of floodplain meadows (key habitats of globally threatened species) through introduction of technology of sustainable use of meadows for mowing and grazing and through development of ecological tourism . 1.6 Ecological tourism developed at key protected areas, resulting in improved financial sustainability of protected areas and raised awareness about importance of globally biodiversity conservation. 2.1 Forest biotopes, subject to special protection, are identified, approved and sustainably managed at an area of 150,000 ha 2.2 Avoided degradation of inefficiently drained forest peatlands (260,000 ha) as a result of development and implementation of the Scheme of Sustainable Use of Drained Forest Peatlands, defining ways of use of each peatland. Demonstration of approaches for the ecological rehabilitation of inefficiently drained peatlands at an area of about 12,456 ha. 3.1 Restored habitats (about 1,820 ha) of globally threatened species (Aquatic warbler, Greater spotted eagle, Great snipe, Black-tailed godwit) within the most important protected areas (Servech, Dikoe) through control of vegetation succession (control of the spread of shrubs and reeds) and optimization of hydrological regime. 3.3 Targeted measures to stabilize populations of insufficiently studied globally threatened species.
